messages.subject: Re: [Unschooling-Discussion] reading; WAS:deschooling
messages.msgSnippet: In a message dated 8/13/03 1:29:48 PM Eastern Daylight Time, ... My dad may very well be dyslexic.  He s never been tested or anything like that.  I do not
messages.messageBody:
In a message dated 8/13/03 1:29:48 PM Eastern Daylight Time,
elizabethogi@... writes:

> I don't know much about it, but could many older adults who never
> learned to read have dyslexia? Was that generation even aware of it?
>

My dad may very well be dyslexic. He's never been "tested" or anything like
that. I do not know exactly what his challanges are in reading. I know that
he does recognize lots of very familar words, small words, but if he doesnt
know a word, he will just skip it, not even try to read it. My sister and my
middle son have similar difficulties with reading. Now, my son has been
"tested"... no dyslexia... more of a processing thing.. And, he can read, it is
just not easy for him

Teresa


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: reading; WAS:deschooling
messages.msgSnippet: ... I don t know much about it, but could many older adults who never learned to read have dyslexia? Was that generation even aware of it? Mothering magazine
messages.messageBody:
> Reading is not natural for my daddy. It confuses and befuddles him, it
> is
> frustrating and exhausting.
>
>
> Teresa
>

I don't know much about it, but could many older adults who never
learned to read have dyslexia? Was that generation even aware of it?
"Mothering" magazine has a good article about it this month: a woman's
"very bright" daughter who just couldn't learn to read without great
effort.

E.
